Provide allergen information for ALL food sold or provided, including loose and PPDS
Label food with nutritional information only
Provide allergen information only when specifically requested by a customer

final.text: Natasha's Law was introduced following the death of:
options: A child who consumed peanuts at a school canteen
Natasha Ednan-Laperouse, who died after eating a Pret a Manger baguette containing sesame
A hotel guest who was served shellfish despite declaring an allergy
A factory worker exposed to airborne wheat flour

final.text: Under the Food Safety Act 1990, the maximum penalty for selling food not of the nature, substance, or quality demanded is:
options: A fixed penalty of 500 pounds
An unlimited fine and/or up to 2 years imprisonment
A written warning for a first offence
A 1,000 pound fine and a 6-month trading ban

final.text: Which of the following is classified as PPDS (Prepacked for Direct Sale)?
options: A steak cooked to order and plated at the customer's table
A sandwich made on-site, wrapped, and placed in a display fridge for customer self-service
A frozen pizza sealed in a factory and sold in a supermarket
A portion of chips served loose in a takeaway container at the customer's request

final.text: The 'one step back, one step forward' traceability principle means:
options: You must be able to trace ingredients one step back to your supplier and one step forward to your customer
You should keep records for one year before and one year after production
You must test each ingredient one step before and one step after cooking
You should check the supplier's supplier and the customer's customer

final.text: Which allergen is commonly hidden in stock cubes, soups, and seasoning mixes?
options: Peanuts
Crustaceans
Celery
Lupin

final.text: Cross-contact differs from cross-contamination in that cross-contact:
options: Only occurs between raw and cooked food
Specifically refers to allergen transfer and cannot be eliminated by cooking
Only happens in factory settings, not restaurants
Is less serious than cross-contamination

final.text: When cleaning equipment for allergen-free production, the correct sequence is:
options: Sanitise, rinse, wash with soapy water, dry
Remove debris, wash with hot soapy water, rinse, sanitise, dry with clean cloth
Spray with anti-bacterial, wipe, air dry
Rinse with cold water, apply sanitiser, air dry

final.text: Allergen-specific lateral flow tests are used to:
options: Test customers for allergies before they eat
Detect specific allergen proteins on cleaned surfaces to validate cleaning effectiveness
Measure the severity of a customer's allergic reaction
Test staff knowledge of the 14 allergens

final.text: A supplier sends you a product with 'New improved recipe' on the label. You should:
options: Use it immediately – improvements are always positive
Quarantine the product and check the updated specification before use
Return it and insist on the old recipe
Add 'may contain all 14 allergens' to your matrix for that product

final.text: The Food Information Regulations 2014 require that for non-prepacked (loose) food, allergen information:
options: Does not need to be available – it is the customer's responsibility
Can be given verbally but must have a written backup available
Must be printed on every plate or serving dish
Only needs to be available in English, regardless of the customer base

final.text: In a restaurant, the 'pass check' for allergen-safe dishes means:
options: The customer checks the dish before accepting it
A named person at the pass verifies the dish is allergen-safe before it leaves the kitchen
The head chef tastes every dish for allergens
The food runner decides if the dish looks safe

final.text: Using 'may contain all 14 allergens' as a blanket declaration on every dish is:
options: Best practice – it covers all possibilities
Not acceptable – PAL must be based on genuine assessed risk, and blanket disclaimers are misleading
Required by law for restaurants that serve more than 50 covers
Acceptable as long as the EHO has been informed

final.text: 'Wheat-free' and 'gluten-free' mean the same thing.
options: True – wheat is the only source of gluten
False – barley, rye, and some oats also contain gluten, so wheat-free does not guarantee gluten-free
True – in UK law they are interchangeable terms
False – but the difference is not relevant for food safety purposes

final.text: The '5 Whys' technique is used in allergen incident investigation to:
options: Identify the 5 most common allergens involved in incidents
Drill down from the immediate cause to the root cause of the failure
Question 5 different staff members about what happened
Determine the 5 steps needed to resolve the incident

final.text: In the event of a customer suffering anaphylaxis on your premises, the first action is to:
options: Consult the allergen matrix to confirm whether an error was made
Call 999 immediately – anaphylaxis is a life-threatening emergency
Contact your insurer before doing anything else
Ask the customer to describe their symptoms for your records

final.text: Allergen near-misses should be:
options: Ignored – no harm was done so there is nothing to investigate
Logged, investigated, and used as learning opportunities to prevent future incidents
Only recorded if a manager witnessed them
Reported to the FSA within 24 hours

final.text: Competency assessment for allergen management should include:
options: A written test only – practical observation is not necessary
Observation during service, questioning on specific dishes, and scenario testing
Simply asking the staff member if they feel confident
Only checking whether they attended the training session

final.text: A PPDS label for an egg and cress sandwich must include:
options: Just the product name and a list of allergens present
Product name, full ingredients list with allergens emphasised, and business name and address
Product name, price, and best-before date only
A QR code linking to allergen information online

final.text: Sulphites must be declared when present at concentrations above:
options: 1 ppm (parts per million)
10 ppm (parts per million)
50 ppm (parts per million)
100 ppm (parts per million)

final.text: Which of the following is NOT one of the 14 declarable allergens in UK law?
options: Lupin
Kiwi
Molluscs
Mustard

final.text: During a busy service, a chef cannot find the allergen matrix. They should:
options: Prepare the allergen-free order from memory – they know the menu well
Stop and locate the matrix before preparing the dish – never prepare an allergen order without checking
Ask another chef what they think is in the dish
Serve the dish with a verbal warning that they could not confirm allergens

final.text: A food business's 'due diligence' defence for allergen safety depends on:
options: Having a good reputation in the local community
Being able to demonstrate that all reasonable precautions were taken and documented
Having an expensive allergen management software system
Never having had a previous allergen incident

final.text: Which piece of legislation makes it an offence to sell food not of the nature, substance, or quality demanded?
options: The Equality Act 2010
The Food Safety Act 1990
The Health and Safety at Work Act 1974
The Consumer Rights Act 2015

final.text: Peanut protein (Ara h 1) is:
options: Destroyed by cooking at temperatures above 75 degrees C
Heat-stable and survives frying, boiling, and baking
Only dangerous when consumed raw
Deactivated by freezing for 24 hours

final.text: For shared equipment (e.g., a mixer used for regular and gluten-free baking), the recommended cleaning validation is:
options: A visual inspection by the baker is sufficient
A documented cleaning SOP supplemented by periodic allergen-specific lateral flow testing
Rinsing with water between uses
Wiping with antibacterial cloths between batches

final.text: When designing a menu, the most effective allergen risk reduction strategy is:
options: Adding 'may contain' warnings to every dish on the menu
Designing allergens out of recipes at the menu-planning stage where possible
Requiring all customers to sign a waiver before ordering
Serving only pre-packed factory food to avoid preparation risks

final.text: A supplier agreement for allergen management should include:
options: Only the price, delivery schedule, and payment terms
Advance notification of ingredient changes, provision of specifications, and the right to reject non-conforming products
A clause stating the supplier takes full legal responsibility for all allergen issues
An agreement to supply the cheapest available product at all times

final.text: Under RIDDOR 2013, an allergen incident must be reported to the HSE when:
options: Any customer reports feeling unwell after eating
A customer or employee dies or suffers a major injury as a result of the incident
A customer uses an EpiPen on the premises, regardless of outcome
Any near-miss involving allergens is identified

final.text: Lupin is most commonly found in which type of product?
options: Dairy products and cheese
Some continental breads, pastries, and flour blends
Fresh fruit and vegetables
Meat and poultry products

final.text: The best approach to allergen management during a banqueting or events service is:
options: Use the same allergen matrix as the restaurant menu – the kitchen is the same
Conduct a separate allergen assessment for each event menu, confirming individual guest requirements in advance
Ask guests with allergies to bring their own food to the event
Only check allergens for the main course, not starters or desserts

final.text: A customer asks about allergens via a third-party delivery app (e.g., Deliveroo, Just Eat). Your responsibility is:
options: None – the delivery platform is responsible for allergen information
To ensure accurate allergen information reaches the end customer, including via the platform and any packaging inserts
To direct the customer to visit the restaurant in person to discuss their allergy
To add a disclaimer that you cannot guarantee allergen safety for deliveries

final.text: In a care home setting, allergen management has a higher duty of care because:
options: Care home food is subject to different legislation than restaurant food
Residents may not be able to identify, communicate, or respond to allergic reactions independently
Care homes do not need to follow PPDS labelling requirements
Care home staff do not need allergen training

final.text: What is the minimum temperature for water used in allergen cleaning?
options: Room temperature (approximately 20 degrees C)
At least 55 degrees C with detergent
At least 82 degrees C (boiling point)
Temperature does not matter if detergent is used

final.text: ATP swabbing after cleaning tells you about:
options: The specific allergens present on the surface
The general biological cleanliness of the surface (but not specifically allergen presence)
Whether the surface has been sanitised against bacteria
The pH level of cleaning chemicals used

final.text: When investigating an allergen incident using the '5 Whys', the goal is to identify:
options: The individual staff member who made the mistake so they can be disciplined
The root cause – the underlying system or process failure that allowed the error to occur
Five different versions of events from five different witnesses
The five most important facts to include in the incident report

final.text: How often should supplier specifications be formally verified (written confirmation that nothing has changed)?
options: Annually, at the contract renewal date
At least quarterly, plus on any delivery where something looks different
Only when a customer complains about an allergen
Every 5 years, in line with food safety management plan reviews

final.text: A server tells a customer with a nut allergy: 'It should be fine – I think the chef uses sunflower oil, not nut oil.' This response is:
options: Helpful and shows good product knowledge
Unacceptable – 'I think' and 'should be' are not confirmed information and could be fatal
Appropriate as a first response before checking further
Correct – sunflower oil never contains nuts

final.text: Digital POS systems that flag allergens on orders are beneficial because they:
options: Eliminate the need for an allergen matrix entirely
Automate the communication of allergen information from order to kitchen, reducing human error
Allow restaurants to operate without allergen-trained staff
Are legally required under Natasha's Law

final.text: In the context of allergen management, 'version control' of the allergen matrix means:
options: Keeping the matrix in a locked cabinet so no one can change it
Dating, signing, and archiving each version so you can track changes over time
Creating a new matrix every day regardless of whether anything changed
Only allowing the head chef to view the current version

final.text: A compound ingredient on a PPDS label must be:
options: Listed by its common name only (e.g., 'mayonnaise')
Broken down into its individual sub-ingredients, with allergens emphasised at every level
Listed only if it contains one of the 14 allergens
Excluded from the label if it makes up less than 2% of the product

final.text: Which of the following is a 'red flag' when checking deliveries?
options: The product arrives at the correct temperature
The packaging or label looks different from the usual product
The delivery driver has the correct paperwork
The quantity matches the order

final.text: The Equality Act 2010 may be relevant to allergen management because:
options: It requires all restaurants to serve allergen-free food
Severe food allergy may be considered a disability, requiring reasonable adjustments
It mandates that all food businesses employ an allergen specialist
It sets the 14 allergens that must be declared

final.text: An allergen incident file should be reviewed by management:
options: Only after a fatal incident
Regularly (at least monthly) to identify patterns and trends
Once a year during the annual audit
Never – incident files are confidential and should be sealed

final.text: A high number of allergen near-miss reports in a business indicates:
options: The business has serious allergen management problems and should be shut down
A strong reporting culture where staff feel safe flagging issues – this is positive
Staff are making too many mistakes and need to be replaced
The allergen matrix is completely wrong and should be discarded

final.text: When a customer suffers anaphylaxis in your restaurant, you should preserve the food because:
options: You need to test it to see if it was good quality
It is critical evidence for the investigation by Environmental Health, police, and your insurer
You can serve it to another customer who does not have allergies
It helps the customer's doctor identify a treatment plan

final.text: Soya is commonly found as a hidden allergen in all of the following EXCEPT:
options: Bread and bakery products
Processed meats and sausages
Fresh whole fruits and vegetables
Chocolate and confectionery

final.text: The 'one person, one dish' principle for allergen-free orders means:
options: Only one customer per table can have an allergen-free meal
The same chef handles the allergen-free order from start to finish to maintain control
Only one dish on the menu can be made allergen-free
One person in the restaurant is responsible for all allergen decisions

final.text: Article 8 of EU FIC 1169/2011 (retained in UK law) places responsibility for allergen information accuracy on:
options: The customer, who should always carry their own allergen information
The food business operator selling the food to the consumer
The food supplier or manufacturer exclusively
The local authority or Environmental Health department

final.text: Which statement about allergen management culture is correct?
options: A blame culture encourages staff to report mistakes quickly
A strong allergen culture means staff feel safe reporting near-misses, leadership invests in systems, and allergic customers feel welcomed
Allergen management culture is only relevant for large chain restaurants
Culture does not matter as long as the paperwork is complete
